For future updates of the course, please consider selecting only one API from one of the four you highlighted (perhaps Google, since they have the playground). Then, show the manual way, and then a code-based approach (choose a popular langugage like Node, Go, Python, etc.).

Your students will not be using API's in a manual way, but having at least one example is useful. It is not necessary to have 4 manual examples.

results.content:
The course is very interesting and delivers what is expected from an introductory course. I appreciate the slow pace and repetition to make the information clearly understood. There are some issues I have with the course and I would have given it 5 stars otherwise:

The pace is too slow and information is repeated so many times. It takes a lot of the course's time to repeat the same information, while it would have been better to tackle some subjects that are not tackled as in the next point.

The course explores only 2 of the 4 OAuth flows (although it covers the Authorization code flow which is the complete one). There is no information or examples on how to use the verify endpoint, which is needed while developing my own Resource server.

My final concern is the course's price. I got it on a black Friday deal for 11$, however, its current price is 95$, which is very expensive for an introductory course.

This is an amazing course, only some minor enhancements can make it perfect

results.content: The guy with the power point slides is not bad. I live visual explanations. But those two guys talks overlap a lot, there is so much redundancy in this course, which makes it kind of boring. What I really hate is the guy sitting before his silly bookshelf with books he probably never read (like a lot of "professionals" nowadays think, that this is what they should do). Rather than a fullscreen cam to his face, I like visual explanations and not just some guy talking. These are learning videos and not some podcasts where you could also just put up a blank screen. It makes the viewer paying attention to all the details instead of focusing on the content. In my opinion, 80% of the videos here could be removed and you would not miss a single thing. It starts getting interesting from Section 5. The rest is very redundant and mostly very boring. I still give 3 Stars because there is good knowledge in here, but my tip for you guys would be to step up your explanation and visualisation game. The powerpoint guy is good and the ideas are nicely presented. Basic, but it works. The other guy has like a ton of cuts in his videos (very annoying) and I don't really see a "main storyline" he tries to follow, just sometimes random examples that somehow make sense but seem misplaced.

results.content:
Nice course, gives a good overall picture of OAuth. 
However, at some points it needs an update: Resource Owner Password Credentials and Implicit flows are not recommended anymore. On the other side, PKCE extension for the Authorization Code flow is clearly missing from the course, as today that's the preferred way over Implicit flow (e.g. for Mobile apps and SPAs).
results.content_html:
Nice course, gives a good overall picture of OAuth.
However, at some points it needs an update: Resource Owner Password Credentials and Implicit flows are not recommended anymore. On the other side, PKCE extension for the Authorization Code flow is clearly missing from the course, as today that's the preferred way over Implicit flow (e.g. for Mobile apps and SPAs).

results.content:
This course provides a good understanding of OAuth2. For beginners that is, to get up to speed on concepts, try a few manual operations using curl, understand application registration, client id/secret and calls for codes, tokens, content.  

As some have complained, while the instructor takes a good deal of care to explain and re-explain in multiple videos, it does seem repetitive at the end. But it will benefit those who jump around and go straight to the PayPal API for example. 

Course could be improved by trimming to 2hrs, adding a programming example for any of the resources sampled.

Repetitive information, EXTREMELY slow presentation, lack of real-time coding examples, and just an overall lack of proper flow.  I purchased the book version of this course; the information is similar, and I think the book would suffice for most anyone.  It's not the premier resource for OAuth2, but it's good as a quick guide/reference.  As far as the course, however, it's a clear failure.

Decent course! Allowed me use OAuth with more confidence, knowing more about what it was doing "under the hood".

However, I think it needs a small update to include PKCE to draw attention to the implicit flow no longer being recommended.

It would also be worth talking about some of the security vulnerabilities in OAuth and the dangers of poo client-side implementation: From https://portswigger.net/web-security/oauth/preventing:

Please keep in mind that there is not much depth in this course. I found that the author repeats the same shallow content too many times to fill time. The first six sections are painfully too long, shallow and repetitive.

results.content:

results.content:
- Audio keeps going in and out (not consistent). I have to keep lowering and raising the volume for each video.
- Please remove any unnecessary music in the background of the videos. The sudden and loud music is unnecessary. This is a training material, not some fashion show.
- Delivery is way too slow. I am listening at 1.5x speed right now to compensate.
- Way too much music at the beginning itself and way too loud (inconsistent audio). 
- For any slides involving a flow, it is good to have the number sequence for the various arrows because it is hard to visualize with just the speaker talking and the picture being so static.
- It will help to have more area of the screen for slides which have content instead of the speaker taking more than 3/4th of the screen. The slides need to have the bullet points being shared by the speaker instead of just 1 icon on the slide. For example, instead of showing a small slide in the top right corner with just 1 icon representing "Authorization server" and the speaker talking about the 3-4 items related to authorization server, those points should be listed on the slide and be available throughout the conversation. As students, we are interested in seeing tangible content/material (not just 1 icon); having the speaker shown is good but not the primary objective.
- I am barely 1/4th done with this course but am losing patience and am not sure if I will finish it.

results.content: This is the best OAuth2 tutorial. The explanations is very clear and sincere. In restrospect, I have now a clear understanding of what are the conceptual stuff that OAuth2 is trying to standardize. The best part of this course is the hands-on actual OAuth2 application in Facebook, Google, LinkedIn and Paypal. And from here, it can be seen that OAuth2 is not a bit for bit exacting standard, but instead a framework that dwells on high level generalization and concepts. Now, I felt confident reading the related RFCs because of the solid grounding that this tutorial has given me.

results.content:
I thought that overall the course was quite informative. Matthias seems to really know his stuff, and I appreciated the examples that he had for LinkedIn, Google, Paypal, etc. 

My only suggestion for future courses by him would maybe be to better design the sections to reduce repetition. I found that the high-level authorization code-style flow was repeated a few times, which made a bit of a mess of the personal notes that I was taking. As well, some of the videos had very low volume while others had normal, meaning I was adjusting my headphone volume between lectures. Finally, it might be helpful if the flow diagrams were numbered in some cases just to show the sequence of flow (although I know the swimlane diagrams do show this).

All being said though, the course was informative and I'm glad to have taken it!

results.content:
The course was pretty good up until Lecture 13 where for some reason the instructor begins to introduce topics that should have be sequenced differently. For example, Lecture 16 should come before 13. Also, why would the access token be introduced first vs the authentication token which is the first step. Makes it confusing to the student. For this to be course with "expert" in the title, the Subway example was pretty lazy to describe tokens. 

The class does get pretty good when he goes into the Code Flow Sections and as a student, you should probably watch those first before lecture 13. Please consider switching these lectures around or tell students that you are going to go more indepth in later sections.

Major talking points are done verbally and should be emphasized in the powerpoint slide visually. For example, when going through the flows, it is mentioned why certain flows are secure. Provide this visually and elaborate on it. Instructor just mentioned "it is secure because access token is not flowing through browser" but did not say why to finish the statement or mention where the access token is actually flowing to finalize the statement and bring it all together.

I did get some value from it so won't continue to talk about the negatives.

results.content: I used to be afraid of OAuth. Up to now, my approach has been to try to figure it out by using a library promising to make it easy. But libraries usually assume that you know OAuth, the grant types, the 4 different flows,etc. The result: I would not get very far in my implementation, and I was not confident in whether I was doing things correctly or not. This course really helped me better understand OAuth. The teacher is great and fun, and I am very impressed by how Matthias went about explaining it. Look forward to animated diagrams that make the whole thing much easier to understand.

results.content:
Pretty informative.  I think if would be easier to understand if the presenter talked about specific problems that need to be solved, and then introduced the OAuth flow that could address that problem.  I also found it difficult to picture the exact workflow being discussed because things will be different for an App and a Web Application.

So in summary, this is useful information and if your interested in OAuth 2.0 then definitely worth your time.  But it didn't blow my socks off by addressing all the questions running around in my head :-)
